What did early Canadian pioneer eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: W. O. Fraser
Address: O'Keefe Ranch
Birthplace: Portage La Prairie, Man
Born: Sept. 23, 1880

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in eastern Canada? 1902
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Bradshaw, Man
   Where had you been living before that? Hamilton, Man
   For how many people did you prepare meals? myself
   How far was it to your nearest store? In Bradshaw
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Any time
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? oat meal
   Sugar, apples, meat from farmers, milk

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Gilmore
   In what quantities did you buy it? 50 pounds per bag
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75 per bag
   How much did you use graham flour? 50 pounds per year
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 40 miles
   What year? 1900
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80 cents
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? A little
   Whole wheat? A little
   Farina? A little
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some whole wheat
   How did you grind it? Stock Crusher Roller

3. **SUGAR AND BUTTER**

   - In what quantity did you buy "Hills" sugar? 20 lbs.
   - What was the price for a ton (per lb.)? $1.50.
   - What brand of butter did you buy? Smith's.
   - What size of tin of butter did you usually buy? 1 lb.

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

   - How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early part of the year?
     - Butter.
     - Cheese.
     - Yogurt.
   - What was the price of butter? 5¢ per lb.
   - Did you purchase from the store? Yes.
   - Did you make butter? No.
   - What kind of cheese?

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

   - What was your meat supply in the early part of the year?
     - Poultry.
     - Pork.
     - Beef.
     - Lamb.
   - How did you get fresh meat?
     - From the store.
     - From the butcher.
     - From the market.
   - How often did you get fresh meat?
     - Weekly.
     - Bi-weekly.
     - Monthly.
   - How did you preserve meat?
     - Canned.
     - Frozen.
     - Dried.
   - Was there a "short time"?
     - Yes.
     - No.
   - If so what year was it?
     - 1920.
   - Did you use games?
     - Yes.
     - No.
   - For how long?
     - 1920.
   - Did you buy fish in the family diet?
     - Yes.
     - No.
   - What kind of fish?
     - Fresh.
     - Salted.
   - Notes:

   - Use the fish fresh, canned or cured.
6. Beverages:
   - What kind of tea did you buy? Black tea.
   - At what price? 40¢.
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground.
   - Price? 25¢.
   - What other beverages were used? Chocolate.

7. Vegetables and Dried Fruits:
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
     - 35¢.
   - Could you get potatoes at the store? No.
   - If not, where from? Farm.
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
     - Potatoes 1902, Cabbages 1902, Carrots 1901, Onions 1902,
     - Turnips 1902, Beets 1904.
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? None.
   - How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? At store.
   - What weight? 10 pounds.
   - How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? None.
   - Monthly bulk.
   - What was the price of prunes? 6¢.
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?
     - Dried and some welch.

8. Preserving:
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
   - Pass? Yes.
   - Corn? Yes.
   - Beans? Yes.
   - Saskatoons? Yes.
   - Other foods? None.
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1910.
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1910.
   - What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1912.
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes.
   - To what extent? Preserve family.
   - Did you make your own vinegar? No, don't know.
   - Mother made vinegar in the years from 1880 to 1920.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Water in Manitoba was in wells. In Saskatchewan, 1910, hauled in two miles in Tank - House Tank in Cellar.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Yes
If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Lye, washing soda

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood
Where did you get your fuel? From the mountain
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) 1880
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) 1920
By whom was your first cook stove made? Copper Bros - Wrightstown
What year was it purchased? 1880
Price? $6.00
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Copper
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware
When did you first see enamel ware? 1920
Aluminum? 1929

Most utensils were done by hand.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

 Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

 Brown paper for wrapping since I can remember or cheap brown paper.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

 Porridge, Eggs, Bacon, Bread, Toast over wood fire. We were on a farm in Hamilton Man. from 1890 to 1900, ages 20-18-16-14-12-8-4.

In 1900.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

 Mother in 1880 at Portage la Prairie myself in 1906 at Sunnyside Manor.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

 No - not personally. From 1932 to 1934 very nearly for some in Okotoks District.

Any food is better than nothing.
Brown Paper from another place.

Never use brown paper.

What did you do at your first Christmas dinner in eastern Idaho?

List five things present and five things absent at the time.

Christmas Eve 1889 at Portage, Idaho

Christmas Eve 1906 at Jackson County, Oregon

No permanent home from 1930 to 1950

1930 very nearly after a move in

Butte

Any history in your family?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We ate from boyhood more from the garden. More home cooking, more wild fruit. Still eat a good deal of the same since 1940 more canned goods, fruit, vegetable, bakers bread.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Us about 1940
Others 1930

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

I was brought up on a farm and our food came from the garden, a great deal of wild fruit tomatoes which we still can.

The majority in our neighborhood even from farms use canned goods do not have a garden, and do not use any wild fruit.

In my boyhood days we always had plenty to eat. We were taught to help all others and to not waste to help any person who can work need not be hungry or cold at any time.
We ate from boyhood on our own garden and fruit. We grew our own vegetables and fruits.

Since 1940 we have canned goods. Fruit Vegetables. Baker Bread.

We almost 1940

Others 1930

I was brought up on a farm and garden. A good deal of our food came from the garden which we grew in our own orchard.

The majority of our food came from our own garden. We did not have any wild game or animals.

In any hurry to eat, we were taught to help ourselves and work out our own way.

Any person who can work out their own way is doing well.
Archives Office Box 100
Saskatoon

Dear Sir,

Western pioneers in Manitoba and Saskatchewan ate very well sixty years ago. Vegetables were a daily portion; more attention was paid to their cultivation then now. With its town and country, breakfast, porridge (at meal), bacon & eggs, tea or coffee.

Dinner:
Meat: Beef, Pork, Chicken, mutton
Potatoes, carrots, cabbage
Carrot peel, Saskatoon or raspberry

Supper:
Cold meat
Fried vegetables
Fruit: Strawberries, raspberries

Not much variation but all good.
Food cooked over a wood fire.
Plenty of wild fruit and food for the hunting and gathering.

W.O. Fraser
Dear Sir,

Lakota Sioux were very much like the pioneers in Manitoba years ago. Vegetables were a daily part of their diet, more attention was paid to their cultivation than now.

Breakfast: Pancake (pancake) Bacon & Eggs

Tea or Coffee

Meat: Beef, Pork (chicken)

Potatoes, Carrots, Cabbage

Carrot Pie, Baskatoon & Rasberry

Dinner

Cold meat, vegetables, fruit all served

Supper

Short amused conversation but all served

Good cooked over a wood fire for the plenty of united fruit and flour for the hearty appetite.

W.O. Fraser
